title: Labour's election campaign will back 'as much freedom of movement as possible' warns John McDonnell
text:
Labour will put itself on a direct electoral collision path with the Conservatives on immigration by campaigning for 'as much freedom of movement as possible', John McDonnell said today.

The shadow chancellor made the pledge as he played up the opposition's chances of winning the expected December 12 vote, saying: 'I can't think of a better Christmas present.'

Mr McDonnell's comments are in direct contrast to the Conservatives, who are set to make tightening up UK borders after Brexit a key plank of their own manifesto.

At the party conference at the start of the month Home Secretary Priti Patel said the UK would introduce an Australian-style points based system after it quits the EU.

But asked today about the possible ending of EU freedom of movement laws, McDonnell said the UK needed immigration into the country.

'We're going to have an immigration policy which has as much freedom of movement as possible,' he told the BBC.

Mr McDonnell insisted the campaign offered a real opportunity for them to secure the keys to Downing Street and get a Labour government.

He said: 'Bring it on, let's have a go, despite it being December and cold and dark .. we're going to have a real go at this and I think we'll win.

'I think we'll have a majority government by Christmas, so I can't think of a better Christmas present.'

It came as Jeremy Corbyn faced a huge battle to keep Labour together during the snap election today amid claims some of his own MPs don't want to see him as PM.

The veteran left-winger insists he is 'ready' for the dramatic pre-Christmas contest, describing it as a 'once in a generation chance for change'.

But the scale of infighting within the party was underlined last night when more than 100 of his own MPs ignored his orders to back holding a snap election.

Former leadership contender Owen Smith has announced he will not be standing in his Pontypridd constituency, citing 'political and personal reasons'

Meanwhile, former leadership contender Owen Smith has announced he will not be standing in his Pontypridd constituency, citing 'political and personal reasons'.

Labour MPs have ridiculed Mr Corbyn and his aides for believing they are on the 'brink of a brave new socialist dawn', despite grim polls for the party and him personally.

One told MailOnline: 'They think it is going to happen, he will be walking into No10. A lot of Labour MPs don't even want that.'

Labour was effectively dragged kicking and screaming into backing an election last night.

For weeks the shadow cabinet and backbenchers had been holding back Mr Corbyn and his closest allies, who were desperate for a poll that is widely seen as the 70-year-old's last chance for power.

But despite voting down a motion to call an election on Monday, Labour was outflanked when it became clear Boris Johnson had secured Liberal Democrat and SNP support for a Bill triggering a ballot in December.
